main.opener: Folks don't always talk, but they carry plenty. You carrying much these days?
variants: Not much. Just some odd mornings at my building. People seem on edge.
Heard the usual talk about who gets what. It’s… uncomfortable.
Been keeping to myself. Less risk that way.
Feels like you can’t be careful enough. Sometimes I wish things felt easier.
I keep it light. Saw neighbors lining up, talking about ration access. Little tense.
Protocols keep shifting — no one’s sure who to trust, even at work.

Carrying a bit too much lately, if I’m honest.

Feels like even the smallest thing draws attention. My BCI score dropped again.
Some days, I just wish I could breathe without planning it.
I guess I am carrying a lot, more than I admit, actually.
There’s this tension all over—building entrances full of nervous neighbors debating access to whatever’s left.
At work, the old patterns don’t work. People are afraid to do anything that stands out. I mostly keep quiet, which isn’t hard.
Had to turn down a dispute between neighbors over medical supplies. That kind of thing used to be normal.
With the Directorate under suspicion, you feel it everywhere. My own score fell because I’m not invisible enough.
Nobody’s neutral now. Wishing for calm just makes me seem out of step.
Feels like if I stand out, even a little, it’ll get worse before it gets better.
I carry more than I let on. Lately, every day is full of careful steps, even outside work.
Rumors fly in the halls—who’s rationed out, who gets early access. People I’ve known for years suddenly watch each other for missteps.
The Directorate badge is a curse now. Folks guess you’re with the enemy, or just hiding something. I try to blend, but it’s like the air itself judges.
A neighbor wanted help mediating this fight over medicine. I had to refuse. That cost me, more than I thought it would.
We used to think the BCI made life fair. Now, one wrong move and you’re on a list you can’t see.
My score drops lower every week. I still come to work. But the silence after I speak? That’s thicker than the old propaganda.
Maybe I used to believe in keeping things smooth. I’m a Harmonist, or I was. Now I just want space to breathe.
I’m tired. All these precautions. Sometimes, I wish I could just say what I see. Maybe that’s why I’m here and not anywhere that matters anymore.
main.emotion: tired, a bit anxious, trying to hide relief at having spoken aloud

emotional.opener: You don’t have to explain yourself to anyone here—sometimes just saying it out loud makes it lighter. I get it.
variants: . Thank you. That helps, actually.
. I'm not used to that... someone actually listening.
. It does make a difference, a little.
. You’re right, I don’t say much most days.
. It feels strange to be... heard.
. I think I just needed to let it out.
. So, thanks.
. Sometimes it feels like no one actually sees you in this city.
. Just being able to say something without it being... tracked somehow, it matters.
. I don't even know why I hold things in anymore.
. I forget what it's like to be honest, even with myself.
. Thanks, really.
. You know, there was a time when I thought I was helping by staying silent—preserving order and all that.
. Now, it’s like the silence just weighs so much more.
. I can’t talk like this anywhere else. It’s always measured, recorded. Here, at least, I can be myself for a little while.
. Most days I feel invisible and exposed at the same time—like I’m holding my breath every second.
. Honestly, saying something real? It almost makes me feel human again.
. You understand. That’s rarer than I thought it’d be in this place.
